All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.12: Laboratory Infrastructure. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. The purpose of this IM is to strengthen the quality of comprehensive HIV prevention, care and treatment program in the Ethiopia’s Federal Prison Administration (FPA). Through this, the FPA will improve access to comprehensive HIV/AIDS program for inmates and the prison community. This IM is expected to improve identification of new HIV infection and linkage to care and treatment program, increase ART service, decrease new HIV infections among the target population and enhance institutional capacity to implement quality comprehensive HIV/AIDS service. The FPA will implement a comprehensive HIV/AIDS program including behavior change communication (BCC), sexually transmitted infection (STI) screening and treatment, HIV testing and counseling (HTC), prevention of mother to child transmission of HIV (PMTCT), antiretroviral therapy (ART), care and support, TB/HIV, laboratory and strategic information (SI) in health facilities of FPA. The program will also build the capacity of the partner to produce and use high quality surveillance and program performance data. The program will contribute in the reduction of HIV related morbidity and mortality among the target population
According to the UNAIDS country progress report 2014, the HIV prevalence among inmates in Ethiopia (except Somali region) is 4.2%. The level of knowledge of HIV prevention is also lower among inmates when compared to the general population; knowledge about anal and oral transmission of HIV is only 58.9% and 42.1% respectively. (HAPCO country progress report 2014). Reports from the Federal Police Hospital indicate that mortality and morbidity of HIV/AIDs is still high in the prison population. Hence HIV/AIDS still remains to be major public health problem among the inmate population.
